description: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

headline: Special Weather Statement issued April 20 at 7:58PM MDT by NWS Rapid City SD
description:
At 758 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 5
miles southwest of Savageton, or 19 miles west of Wright, moving
northeast at 25 mph.

Pea size hail and winds in excess of 40 mph will be possible with
this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Savageton.

headline: Flood Warning issued April 20 at 9:43PM EDT until April 29 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
description:
Big Blue River...Driftwood River...East Fork White River...Flatrock
River...Mississinewa River...Muscatatuck River...Wabash River...
White River...Wildcat Creek...Youngs Creek...

.Lowland flooding has developed and will continue to develop across
many area rivers and streams across Indiana. Approximately 2 to 3
plus inches of rain have fallen across portions of central Indiana
since Thursday morning, with locally higher amounts. Rain has ended
across the area with dry weather expected until Tuesday. Flooding
along smaller creeks and streams will end by tomorrow with the
larger rivers remaining in flood through the rest of the week.
The Flood Warning continues for
The East Fork White River near Rivervale.
* from Sunday morning to Monday April 29.
* At  8:30 PM Saturday the stage was 17.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 20.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Sunday morning and continue to
rise to near 26.7 feet by Wednesday morning.  It will fall below
flood stage by Sunday April 28.
* At 28.0 feet...Extensive river flooding in progress.  Residential
areas near the river begin to flood.  The county bridge locally
known as the Buddha bypass bridge becomes inaccessible.   Several
local roads are flooded including Duncan Rd/Tunnelton Rd...Fort
Ritner at the underpass and post office...Old Buddha Rd...Tunnelton
Rd at the RR crossing and West Sparksville Bridge Rd.

Pea size hail and wind gusts up to 50 mph will be possible.

Locations impacted include...
Logan, Brigham City, Hyrum, Perry, Wellsville, Willard, Mantua,
Corinne, South Willard, Benson, North Logan, Providence, Nibley, Hyde
Park, Millville, River Heights, Honeyville, Mendon, Paradise and
College Ward.

description:

Dime size hail, brief moderate to heavy rain, and winds in excess of
40 mph are possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Columbus, Joliet, Absarokee, Park City and Boyd.

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued April 20 at 8:37PM EDT until April 21 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
description:
Leftover large surf and long period swell from the strong
southerly flow on Friday will result in a high threat of rip
currents Sunday for the beaches north and south of Cape Hatteras.
The National Weather Service in Newport/Morehead City has issued
a Beach Hazards Statement, which is in effect from 8 AM EDT
Sunday through Sunday evening.

* HAZARDS...A high risk of rip currents and a strong longshore
current.

* LOCATIONS...Eastern North Carolina Beaches from Oregon Inlet
to Beaufort Inlet.

* TIMING AND TIDES...The most likely time for strong rip currents
to occur is a couple hours around low tide, which will occur
around 330 PM.

area: Eastern Clinton; Grand Isle; Eastern Essex; Western Addison; Western Chittenden; Western Franklin
headline: Special Weather Statement issued April 20 at 7:32PM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
description:
At 0730 PM EDT, surface observations and several webcams across
the Champlain Valley indicate areas of patchy dense fog throughout
the region. Visibilities of a half mile or less are expected,
especially in and along Lake Champlain. Motorists should use
extreme caution while traveling in this area. Slow down and leave
plenty of room between you and the car in front of you.

area: Cape Decision to Salisbury Sound Coastal Area
headline: High Wind Watch issued April 20 at 3:31PM AKDT until April 22 at 1:00PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
description:
The National Weather Service in Juneau has issued a High Wind
Watch, which is in effect from Monday morning through Monday
afternoon.

* LOCATION...Central outer coast including Sitka and Port
Alexander.

* WINDS...Southwest to 40 mph with gusts to 60 mph or more
possible.

* TIMING...Early Monday morning through early Monday afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Trees could be blown down by the wind. Power outages
are possible.

headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 20 at 2:02PM AKDT until April 22 at 6:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks, AK
description:
* WHAT...Snow and blowing snow expected. Plan on difficult travel
conditions. In addition, areas of poor visibility are expected.
Total snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches are expected.

* WHERE...Yukon Delta.

* WHEN...10 PM Sunday to 6 PM Monday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Winds gusting as high as 40 mph will cause
areas of blowing and drifting snow.

area: Lower Koyukuk and Middle Yukon Valleys
headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 20 at 2:02PM AKDT until April 22 at 4:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks, AK
description:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Plan on difficult travel conditions. Total
snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches, with localized amounts up
to 6 inches, are expected. In addition, areas of poor visibility
are expected.

* WHERE...Lower Koyukuk and Middle Yukon Valleys.

* WHEN...4 PM Sunday to 4 PM Monday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Winds gusting as high as 40 mph will cause
areas of blowing and drifting snow. Highest wind gusts over
high terrain.

area: Western Nevada Basin and Range including Pyramid Lake
headline: Lake Wind Advisory issued April 20 at 2:35PM PDT until April 21 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Reno NV
description:
The National Weather Service in Reno has issued a Lake Wind
Advisory for Pyramid Lake, which is in effect from noon to 8 PM
PDT Sunday.

* Winds: This evening, southwest 15 to 20 mph with gusts to 35
mph. Sunday, northwest to north 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to
40 mph.

* Wave Heights: This evening 1 to 3 feet with highest waves north
and east shores. For Sunday, 1 to 4 feet with highest waves on
the south shore.

* Small boats, kayaks and paddle boards will be prone to
capsizing and should remain off lake waters until conditions
improve.

area: Coastal Cumberland; Knox; Coastal York; Coastal Rockingham; Sagadahoc; Lincoln; Coastal Waldo
headline: Coastal Flood Statement issued April 20 at 4:55PM EDT until April 21 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Gray ME
description:
Peak astronomical tides and an onshore flow will lead to higher
than normal water levels along the coast tonight. In addition,
5 to 9 foot nearshore waves may allow for minor beach
erosion and minor splash-over near the time of high tide shortly
after midnight.
* TIMING...From midnight tonight to 2 AM EDT Sunday.

* Impacts...Minor beach erosion and minor splash-over possible
along vulnerable beaches.

* Location...The Seacoast of New Hampshire as well as the
Southwest Coast and Midcoast region of Maine.

area: Coastal Harris; Coastal Brazoria; Galveston Island and Bolivar Peninsula; Inland Brazoria; Inland Harris; Coastal Galveston; Brazoria Islands; Inland Galveston
headline: Air Quality Alert issued April 20 at 1:31PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
description:
THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (TCEQ)...HAS ISSUED AN
OZONE ACTION DAY FOR THE HOUSTON...GALVESTON...AND BRAZORIA AREAS FOR
SUNDAY APRIL 21 2019.

ATMOSPHERIC CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED TO BE FAVORABLE FOR PRODUCING
HIGH LEVELS OF OZONE POLLUTION IN THE HOUSTON...GALVESTON AND
SURROUNDING AREAS ON SUNDAY. YOU CAN HELP PREVENT OZONE POLLUTION BY
SHARING A RIDE...WALKING...RIDING A BICYCLE...TAKING YOUR LUNCH TO
WORK...AVOIDING DRIVE THROUGH LANES...CONSERVING ENERGY AND KEEPING YOUR
VEHICLE PROPERLY TUNED.

FOR MORE INFORMATION ON OZONE:

OZONE: THE FACTS (WWW.TCEQ.TEXAS.GOV/AIRQUALITY/MONOPS/OZONEFACTS.HTML)
EPA AIR NOW:
(WWW.AIRNOW.GOV/INDEX.CFM?ACTION=AIRNOW.LOCAL_CITY&CITYID=236)

headline: Flood Advisory issued April 20 at 7:51AM EDT by NWS Marquette MI
description:
Manistique River near Manistique affecting Schoolcraft County

.Warmer temperatures throughout the weekend combined with recent
rainfall will continue to enable runoff from the melting snowpack.
Snowpack remains across the northern areas of the Manistique
River Basin. The river is expected to remain above bankfull
throughout the weekend into early next week. Moderate to heavy
rain is possible Monday into early Tuesday.
The National Weather Service in Marquette has issued a
* Flood Advisory for
The Manistique River near Manistique.
* until further notice.
* At 6 AM Saturday the stage was 11.1 feet.
* Bankfull stage is 11.0 feet.
* At 10.5 feet...Considerable overflow of riverbanks and flooding of
low lying wooded areas in the vicinity of the gauge is occurring.

headline: Flood Watch issued April 20 at 5:34AM MDT until April 21 at 6:00AM MDT by NWS Missoula MT
description:
The National Weather Service in Missoula has issued a

* Flood Watch for the South Fork Clearwater River at Stites.

* Through late tonight.

* Primary area of concern: South Fork Clearwater River at Stites,
which could reach minor flood stage this morning. Minor stream
and creek flooding is also possible throughout the remainder of
the area.

* Basis for the watch: Periods of moderate to heavy rain will
combine with snow melt to produce considerable runoff across
north- central Idaho. Streams and creeks may reach near
bankfull with mainstream rivers rising considerably, thus minor
flooding is possible.

headline: Flood Advisory issued April 19 at 11:54AM EDT until April 20 at 11:53PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
description:
French Broad River At Asheville affecting Buncombe County

Heavy rain moving across the area has saturated the ground and caused
river levels to rise. Additional rainfall will likely cause the river
to crest just below flood stage.
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a
* Flood Advisory for
The French Broad River At Asheville.
* until Saturday evening.
* At 11 AM Friday the stage was 5.7 feet.
* Action Stage is 6.5 feet.
* Minor Flood Stage is 9.5 feet.
* FORECAST: The river will rise to near 9.3 feet by Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS: At 10.5 feet: Minor Flooding continues.  French Broad River
floodwaters may be approaching industrial buildings on the right
bank between Woodfin and Pearson Bridge Rd.  Floodwaters may also
be approaching industrial buildings between Haywood Rd. and Amboy
Rd..
* IMPACTS: At 9.5 feet: Minor Flood Stage.  The French Broad River is
flooding areas between Riverside Dr., and Lyman St. on the right
bank and Riverview Dr., Craven St. and Emma Rd. on the left bank,
including railroad and industrial property.  Parts of Emma Rd.
between Pearson Bridge Rd. and Craven St. may be flooding..
* IMPACTS: At 8.0 feet: Action stage flooding continues.  The French
Broad River is beginning to flood low-lying areas near Pearson
Bridge Rd. and may be approaching industrial property..
* IMPACTS: At 7.5 feet: Action stage flooding continues.  French Broad
River floodwaters continue to flood Woodfin Riverside Park, the
floodplain adjacent to Craggy Dam Reservoir, Carrier Park, and
French Broad River Park as well as other low-lying areas within the
flood plain.  Floodwaters may be approaching Amboy Rd. and Lyman
St.  Local small tributaries including Smith Mill Creek near Emma
Rd. may be exceeding bankfull levels..
* IMPACTS: At 6.5 feet: Action Stage.  The French Broad River is
exceeding its banks and beginning to flood low-lying areas,
including the Woodfin Riverside Park, the floodplain adjacent to
Craggy Dam Reservoir, Carrier Park, and French Broad River Park..

area: Windsor; Northern Franklin; Eastern Essex; Western Franklin; Western Clinton; Eastern Franklin; Eastern Rutland; Lamoille; Caledonia; Southwestern St. Lawrence; Western Addison; Western Rutland; Essex; Eastern Chittenden; Grand Isle; Eastern Clinton; Western Essex; Southern Franklin; Northern St. Lawrence; Orleans; Washington; Orange; Eastern Addison; Southeastern St. Lawrence; Western Chittenden
headline: Flood Watch issued April 18 at 3:55AM EDT until April 21 at 12:00PM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
description:
The National Weather Service in Burlington has issued a

* Flood Watch for all of northern New York, and all of central and
northern Vermont.

* From Friday evening through Sunday morning.

* Moderate to locally heavy rainfall Friday into Saturday along
with snowmelt in higher elevations will lead to sharp rises on
many local rivers and streams. Main stem rivers most at risk for
flooding include the Passumpsic, the Wells, the Missisquoi, the
Lamoille, the Winooski, the Ausable, and the Saranac Rivers.
Sharp river rises will begin Friday. Most main stem rivers are
expected to crest during the day Saturday into the first part of
Saturday night. Additionally, Lake Champlain may approach of
exceed minor flood stage by this weekend or early next week.

* Those with interests in low-lying or flood prone areas should
continue to monitor the latest forecasts.
